p.s: Personally, I still do believe that there are barriers to success in America.
Even though it fits Obama's image as the first black president, the President of equality etc. one cannot ignore the obstacles still in the path of minorities today.
Statistically, if you grow up poor in America, you're going to die poor too.
Colleges in America require astronomically high tuition fees, the better the college, the more you pay.
Good luck, the health care system of the united statesUnited States is not the one to turn to.
It's true again, the more money you have to begin with, the better your chances.
Another thing - racism is still present.
Black people have lower job acceptance rates than white people with the same qualifications.
Just removing the name and photo from your resume helps with even getting an interview.
How is skin color or being a migrant not a barrier for success then?
The most succesfulsuccessful people in America are white men, women make up half of the population, still the great majority in congress and in high-paying positions are men.
With all these facts and factors in mind, I cannot objectively agree with Obama's statement, though I do understand the rhetorical effect and need for it.
